sentence.text: The patient, now 15 years of age, was initially referred for medical genetics consultation at age 10 regarding short stature, renal cysts, and dental anomalies.
He was born after an uneventful pregnancy in Pakistan, but birth records are not available.
He had one early hospitalization for a febrile illness, but otherwise his early childhood, including achievement of developmental milestones, was completely normal.
His parents are both originally from Pakistan and are fourth cousins.
He has two healthy younger siblings and there is no family history of dental or renal anomalies.
He was evaluated by nephrology and urology after initially presenting with enuresis.
Investigations revealed multiple small renal cysts, chronic renal failure, and hypertension.
On presentation at age 12, a 24 hr urine analysis showed a creatinine clearance of 86 ml/min/1.73m2 with a urine output of 1264 ml/m2/d.

Further, testing showed that his kidney function is declining at a rate of approximately 7 ml/min/1.73m2/year and he will be expected to require renal replacement therapy at the age of 23 years with this rate of decline.
His urinalysis has been normal with a normal protein: creatinine ratio of 15 mg:mmol.
Serial imaging of his liver has identified multiple regions of abnormal echogenicity, but despite that, liver function tests have been repeatedly normal.
He is also missing several permanent teeth.
An ophthalmology examination by a retinal specialist at age 15 revealed normal eyes, normal vision, and no clinical evidence of retinal disease.
On initial presentation at age 12 his height was 110 cm (−5 SD), weight was 20 kg (−3 SD), and head circumference was 51.5 cm (25th percentile).
On examination at age 15 he has short stature (height of 126 cm (−6 SD).
Head shape is normal, as is hair texture and distribution.
He has epicanthal folds and multiple missing teeth but no other craniofacial differences.
He has a narrow chest (Fig. 1), with chest circumference 58.8 cm (<3 percentile) and inter-nipple distance 12 cm (<3rd percentile).
He has small hands (hand length 13.8 cm and palm length of 8 cm, both well below 3rd centile) and feet (foot length 17 cm) and a muscular build.

Further, investigations reveal a delayed bone age and a number of non-specific findings on skeletal survey including short ribs, fusion of L4, and L5 vertebral bodies, relative shortening of the tubular bones and distal phalanges of the feet (Fig. 2).
Despite, his small size he is active and a remarkable athlete, and participates in competitive sports.
He has no major issues with school performance.
